page.title: 9.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will gain understanding of the structure of perfect-square expressions. This lesson will also help you see that perfect squares can be handy for solving equations because we can find their square roots.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Recognize perfect-square expressions written in different forms.
  • Recognize quadratic equations that have a perfect-square expression and solve the equations.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 9.1.1: Equations with Quadratic Expressions on Both Sides of the Equal Sign
  • 9.1.2: Recognizing Structure in Perfect-Square Expressions
    • 9.1.2: Self Check
    • 9.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.1.3: Solving Multi Step Quadratic Equations Using Perfect Squares
    • 9.1.3: Self Check
    • 9.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.1.4: Explain Why an Expression Is a Perfect Square

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 9.1.5: Practice
  • 9.1.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 9.1.1: Equations with Quadratic Expressions on Both Sides of the Equal Sign
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

In each equation, what expression could be substituted for \(a\) so the equation is true for all values of \(x\)?

  1. \(x^2=a^2\)

Enter the expression that could be substituted for \(a\).

Compare your answer:

The correct answer is \(a=x\).


  1. \((3x)^2=a^2\)

Enter the expression that could be substituted for \(a\).

Compare your answer:

The correct answer is \(a=3x\).


  1. \(a^2=7x\cdot7x\)

Enter the expression that could be substituted for \(a\).

Compare your answer:

The correct answer is \(a=7x\).


  1. \(25x^2=a^2\)

Enter the expression that could be substituted for \(a\).

Compare your answer:

The correct answer is \(a=5x\).


  1. \(a^2= \frac {1}{4}x^2\)

Enter the expression that could be substituted for \(a\).

Compare your answer:

The correct answer is \(a=\frac {1}{2}x\).


  1. \(a^2=(x+1)^2\)

Enter the expression that could be substituted for \(a\).

Compare your answer:

The correct answer is \(a=x+1\).


  1. \((2x−9)(2x−9)=a^2\)

Enter the expression that could be substituted for \(a\).

Compare your answer:

The correct answer is \(a=2x-9\).

page.title: 9.1.2: Recognizing Structure in Perfect-Square Expressions
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Each expression is written as the product of factors. Write an equivalent expression in standard form.
  1. \((3x)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(9x^2\)


  1. \(7x \cdot 7x\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(49x^2\)


  1. \((x+4)(x+4)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2+8x+16\)


  1. \((x+1)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2+2x+1\)


  1. \((x−7)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2−14x+49\)


  1. \((x+n)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2+2nx+n^2\)


  1. Why do you think the following expressions can be described as perfect squares?

\(x^2+6x+9\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x^2−16x+64\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x^2+ \frac {1}{3}x+ \frac {1}{36}\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

If these expressions are written in factored form, each one is the square of a linear expression:

\((x+3)^2\), \((x−8)^2\), and \((x+\frac {1}{6})^2\).


Extending Your Thinking

Write each expression in factored form.

  1. \(x^4−30x^2+225\)

Enter the factored form of this expression.

Compare your answer:

\((x^2−15)^2\)

  1. \(x+14\sqrt{x}+49\)

Enter the factored form of this expression.

Compare your answer:

\((\sqrt{x}+7)^2\)

  1. \(5^{2x}+6\cdot 5^x+9\)

Enter the factored form of this expression.

Compare your answer:

\((5^x+3)^2\)

page.title: 9.1.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is equivalent to \((x-4)^2\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Make sure to remember \((x-4)^2=(x-4)(x-4)\). The answer is \(x^2-8x+16\).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Make sure to remember \((x-4)^2=(x-4)(x-4)\). The answer is \(x^2-8x+16\).
That's correct! Check yourself: \((x-4)^2=(x-4)(x-4)\). Then use the distributive property (FOIL).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: When multiplying \((x - 4)(x - 4)\), the product gives a \(-4x + -4x\). The answer is \(x^2-8x+16\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 9.1.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Creating Perfect Square Trinomials

A perfect square trinomial is created by multiplying a binomial by itself.

Example

Write \((x-2)^2\) as an expanded polynomial in standard form:

Step 1
Multiply the binomial by itself.
\((x-2)(x-2)\)

Step 2
Use the distributive property to expand (FOIL).
\(x^2-2x-2x+4\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(x^2-4x+4\)

Try It: Creating Perfect Square Trinomials

Write \((x+5)^2\) as an expanded polynomial in standard form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to expand the polynomial:

Step 1
Multiply the binomial by itself.
\((x+5)(x+5)\)

Step 2
Use the distributive property (FOIL).
\(x^2 +5x+5x+25\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(x^2+10x+25\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.1.3: Solving Multi Step Quadratic Equations Using Perfect Squares
page.contents:
Activity

Han and Jada solved the same quadratic equation with different methods. Here they are:

Han's method:

\(\begin{aligned}(x-6)^{2} &=25 \\ (x-6)(x-6) &=25 \\ x^{2}-12 x+36 &=25 \\ x^{2}-12 x+11 &=0 \\ (11-x)(x-1) &=0 \\ (x-11)(x-1) &=0(x-11) \\ (x-6)^{2} &=25 \\ (x-6)(x-6) &=25 \\ x^{2}-12 x+36 &=25 \\ x^{2}-12 x+11 &=0 \\ (x-11) &=0 \\ (x-1) &=0 \\ x=11 \text { or } x &=1 \end{aligned}\)

Jada's method:

\(\begin{aligned}(x-6)^{2} &=25 \\ \sqrt{(x-6)^{2}} &= \sqrt{25} \\ x-6 &=\pm 5 \\ x-6 &=5 \\ x-6 &=-5 \\ x=11 \text { or } x &=1\end{aligned}\)

Work with a partner to solve these equations. For each equation, one partner solves with Han's method, and the other partner solves with Jada's method. Make sure both partners get the same solutions to the same equation. If not, work together to find your mistakes.

  1. \((y−5)^2=49\)

Enter the solution to this equation.

Compare your answer:

\(y=12\) and \(y=-2\)


  1. \((x+4)^2=9\)

Enter the solution to this equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=-1\) and \(x=-7\)


  1. \((z+ \frac {1}{3})^2=49\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(z=6.\overline6\) or \(6 \frac {2}{3}\) and \(z=-7.\overline3\) or \(-7\frac {1}{3}\)


  1. \((v−0.1)^2= 0.36\)

Enter the solution to this equation.

Compare your answer:

\(v=0.7\) and \(v=-0.5\)


Video: Learning About Solving Multi Step Quadratic Equations Using Perfect Squares

Watch the following video to learn more about solving multi step quadratic equations using perfect squares.

page.title: 9.1.3: Self Check
page.contents: Find all solutions to \((x-3)^2=25\).

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: While this is one solution, there are two. Make sure to set up two equations after taking the square root of both sides. The correct answer is \(x=-2\), \(x=8\).
That's correct! Check yourself: Take the square root of each side. Then be sure to set up two equations.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Be sure to take the square root of both sides of the equation. The correct answer is \(x=-2\), \(x=8\).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Be sure to take the square root of both sides of the equation AND set up two equations. The correct answer is \(x=-2\), \(x=8\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 9.1.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Two Ways to Solve Quadratic Equations

In the activity, Han and Jada used two different methods for solving a quadratic equation, using the distributive property and the square root property.

Using the Distributive Property to Solve Quadratic Equations

How to Solve a Quadratic Equation Using the Distributive Property:

Step 1
Isolate the quadratic term and make its coefficient 1.

Step 2
Rewrite the term so the binomial is multiplied by itself.

Step 3
Use the distributive property or FOIL.

Step 4
Combine like terms so that the equation is set equal to 0.

Step 5
Factor.

Step 6
Set each factor equal to 0.

Step 7
Solve.

Step 8
Check the solutions.


Example

Solve \(4(x-7)^2=36\)

Step 1
Isolate the quadratic term (divide by 4).
\((x-7)^2=9\)

Step 2
Rewrite the term so the binomial is multiplied by itself.
\((x-7)(x-7)=9\)

Step 3
Use the distributive property or FOIL.
\(x^2-7x-7x+49=9\)

Step 4
Combine like terms so that the equation is set equal to 0.
\(x^2-14x+40=0\)

Step 5
Factor.
\((x-10)(x-4)=0\)

Step 6
Set each factor equal to 0.
\(x-10=0\), \(x-4=0\)

Step 7
Solve.
\(x-10=0\;\;\;\;\;\;x-4=0\)
\(x=10\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x=4\)

Step 8
Check the solutions.
\(4(10-7)^2=36\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;4(4-7)^2=36\)
\(4(3)^2=36\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;4(-3)^2=36\)
\(36=36\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;36=36\)

Try It: Using the Distributive Property to Solve Quadratic Equations

Use the distributive property to solve \(3(x-4)^2=48\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to solve the quadratic equation using the distributive property.

Step 1
Isolate the quadratic term (divide by 4).
\((x-4)^2=16\)

Step 2
Rewrite the term so the binomial is multiplied by itself.
\((x-4)(x-4)=16\)

Step 3
Use the distributive property or FOIL.
\(x^2-4x-4x+16=16\)

Step 4
Combine like terms so that the equation is set equal to 0.
\(x^2-8x=0\)

Step 5
Factor.
\(x(x-8)=0\)

Step 6
Set each factor equal to 0.
\(x=0\) or \(x-8=0\)

Step 7
Solve.
\(x=0\;\;\;\;\;\;x-8=0\)
\(x=0\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x=8\)

Step 8
Check the solutions.
\(3(8-4)^2=48\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;3(0-4)^2=48\)
\(3(4)^2=48\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;3(-4)^2=48\)
\(48=48\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;48=48\)

Using the Square Root Property to Solve Quadratic Equations

If \(x^2=k\), then

\(\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x=\sqrt{k}\;\;\;\;\;\;\)or\(\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x=-\sqrt{k}\;\;\;\;\;\;\)or\(\;\;\;\;\;\;x=\pm\sqrt{k}\)

How to Solve a Quadratic Equation Using the Square Root Property:

Step 1
Isolate the quadratic term and make its coefficient one.

Step 2
Use the square root property. Take the square root of both sides of the equation and remember the "plus or minus."

Step 3
Rewrite the equation as two equations.

Step 4
Solve each equation.

Step 5
Check the solutions.


Example

Solve \(4(x-7)^2=36\)

Step 1
Isolate the quadratic term (divide by 4).
\((x-7)^2=9\)

Step 2
Use the square root property.
\(\sqrt{(x-7)^2}=\sqrt{9}\)
\(x-7=\pm 3\)

Step 3
Rewrite the equation as two equations.
\(x-7=-3\)
\(x-7=3\)

Step 4
Solve each equation.
\(x-7=-3\;\;\;\;\;\;x-7=3\)
\(x=4\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x=10\)

Step 5
Check the solutions.
\(4(4-7)^2=36\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;4(10-7)^2=36\)
\(4(-3)^2=36\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;4(3)^2=36\)
\(36=36\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;36=36\)

Try It: Using the Square Root Property to Solve Quadratic Equations

Use the square root property to solve \(3(x-4)^2=48\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to solve the quadratic equation using the square root property:

Step 1
Isolate the quadratic term (divide by 3).
\((x-4)^2=16\)

Step 2
Use the square root property.
\(\sqrt{(x-4)^2}=\sqrt{16}\)
\(x-4=\pm 4\)

Step 3
Rewrite the equation as two equations.
\(x-4=4\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x-4=-4\)

Step 4
Solve each equation.
\(x-4=4\;\;\;\;\;\;x-4=-4\)
\(x=8\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x=0\)

Step 5
Check the solutions.
\(3(8-4)^2=48\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;3(0-4)^2=48\)
\(3(4)^2=48\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;3(-4)^2=48\)
\(48=48\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;48=48\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.1.4: Explain Why an Expression Is a Perfect Square
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

  1. Explain why it makes sense to call the expression \(x^2+20x+100\) a perfect square.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

It is equivalent to \((x+10)^2\), so it is a factor squared.


  1. Solve \(x^2+20x+100=81\).

Enter the solution to this equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x = -1\) and \(x = -19\)

page.title: 9.1.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Select three expressions that are perfect squares.

Correct! \((x+5)(x+5), (-9+c)(c−9), (a+b)(b+a)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \((x+5)(x+5), (-9+c)(c−9), (a+b)(b+a)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Each diagram represents the square of an expression or a perfect square. Complete the cells in the last table by answering questions a–d.

Diagram 1

Diagram 2

Diagram 3

  1. What is the answer for Cell 1 in Diagram 3?

Correct! \(h^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.1 and 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(h^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the answer for Cell 2 in Diagram 3?

Correct! \(\frac {1}{3}h\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.1 and 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(\frac {1}{3}h\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the answer for Cell 3 in Diagram 3?

Correct! \(\frac {1}{3}h\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.1 and 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(\frac {1}{3}h\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the answer for Cell 4 in Diagram 3?

Correct! \((\frac {1}{3})^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.1 and 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((\frac {1}{3})^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Think about the similarities among Diagrams 1, 2, and 3. Additionally, consider Diagram 4, which represents \((term\_1+term\_2)^2\). Then, answer questions a–d.

  1. Choose an observation about Cell 1 in Diagram 4.

Correct! Cell 1 contains the square of the first term.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.1 and 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Cell 1 contains the square of the first term. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Choose an observation about Cell 2 in Diagram 4.

Correct! Cell 2 contains the product of the two terms.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.1 and 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Cell 2 contains the product of the two terms. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Choose an observation about Cell 3 in Diagram 4.

Correct! Cell 3 contains the product of the two terms.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.1 and 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Cell 3 contains the product of the two terms. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Choose an observation about Cell 4 in Diagram 4.

Correct! Cell 4 contains the square of the second term.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.1 and 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Cell 4 contains the square of the second term. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Answer questions a–c regarding Diagram 4 and the standard form of a quadratic, \(ax^2+ bx + c\).

Diagram 4

\((term\_1+term\_2)^2\)

term_1

term_2

term_1

Cell 1

Cell 2

term_2

Cell 3

Cell 4

  1. How is the \(ax^2\) of a perfect square in standard form related to the two terms in Diagram 4 \((term\_1+term\_2)^2\)?

Correct! \(ax^2\) is the square of term 1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(ax^2\) is the square of term 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. How is the \(bx\) of a perfect square in standard form related to the two terms in Diagram 4 \((term\_1+term\_2)^2\)?

Correct! \(bx\) is twice the product of term 1 and term 2.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(bx\) is twice the product of term 1 and term 2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. How is the \(c\) of a perfect square in standard form related to the two terms in Diagram 4 \((term\_1+term\_2)^2\)?

Correct! \(c\) is the square of term 2.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(c\) is the square of term 2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Rewrite the perfect-square expressions.
  1. Rewrite the perfect-square expression \((n+7)^2\) in standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\).

Correct! \(n^2+14n+49\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(n^2+14n+49\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Rewrite the perfect-square expression \((5-m)^2\) in standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\).

Correct! \( m^2-10m+25\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \( m^2-10m+25\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Rewrite the perfect-square expression \((h+ \frac {1}{3})^2\) in standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\).

Correct! \(h^2+\frac {2}{3}h+\frac {1}{9}\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(h^2+\frac {2}{3}h+\frac {1}{9}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Solve each equation, then choose the two solutions.
  1. \((x-1)^2=4\)

Correct! \(x= -1\) and \(x=3\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.3 and 9.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x= -1\) and \(x=3\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x+5)^2=81\)

Correct! \(x= -14\) and \(x=4\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.3 and 9.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x= -14\) and \(x=4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x+11)^2=121\)

Correct! \(x=0\) and \(x = -22\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.3 and 9.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x=0\) and \(x = -22\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x-7)^2=\frac {64}{49}\)

Correct! \(x= \frac {41}{7}\) and \(x = \frac {57}{7}\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.3 and 9.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x= \frac {41}{7}\) and \(x = \frac {57}{7}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Solve the equation \((x-2)^2=0\).

Enter the solution to the equation.

Correct! \(x=2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.1.3 and 9.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x=2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 9.1.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Recognize perfect-square expressions written in different forms.
  • Recognize quadratic equations that have a perfect-square expression and solve the equations.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 9.1.1: Equations with Quadratic Expressions on Both Sides of the Equal Sign
    • In this activity, you determined what needed to be substituted for \(a\) in order to create a true equation.
  • 9.1.2: Recognizing Structure in Perfect-Square Expressions
    • In this activity, you multiplied binomial expressions to create perfect squares.
    • 9.1.2: Self Check
    • 9.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.1.3: Solving Multi Step Quadratic Equations Using Perfect Squares
    • In this activity, you solved quadratic equations using two different methods. One method involved taking the square root of both sides of the equation. The other method involved multiplying two binomials and then factoring.
    • 9.1.3: Self Check
    • 9.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.1.4: Explain Why an Expression Is a Perfect Square
    • In this activity, you explained why we call an expression a perfect square and you solved a factored form of a quadratic equation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 9.1.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
